comments.body:
can you add a bit more comments on what you are trying to achieve here?

maybe best to just put a more full doc-string at the top
Wouldn't the `pop` above already ensure that this was dict_like to begin with?

I updated some other areas to match the current implementation of `DataFrame.plot.box`. Namely, non-dict values of `color` are now passed as the parameter for all color fields (and tests added) and default scheme generation uses "k" for caps just like the DataFrame version.

Here I think the `pop` is being called on `kwds`, which is a dict, so it doesn't any assumptions on the data type of the value at the key "color"
Right but wouldn't this throw an AttributeError two lines up if it wasn't dict_like? Seems like this block can be removed

I don't believe it would because there is a test where `color` is a string with the expectation that the string is used as the color for all elements (test on line 186 below).

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/041f325be006afbad5186b226acc6db89018defe/pandas/tests/plotting/test_boxplot_method.py#L178-L194
Still somewhat confused by this. If it's a string wouldn't the `.pop` call two lines up fail before this ever even hits the `is_dict_like` check?

For simplicity, let's say the only kwds that are passed to boxplot are `color` and `vert=True`.

Suppose `color` is a string, like `"r"`. Then kwds will be `{color: "r", vert: True}` and popping kwd's value at the key "color" will yield `"r"` and assign it to `color`

Suppose `color` is a dict, like `{boxes: "r", whiskers: "b"}`. Then kwds will be `{color: {boxes: "r", whiskers: "b"}, vert: True`, or a dict where one of its values is another dict. Then, popping kwd's value at the key "color" will yield the dict `{boxes: "r", whiskers: "b"}` and assign it to `color`

Then we need to call `is_dict_like` on `color` because at this point it could be a dict or a string
Ah OK thanks for explaining. I was getting tripped up between `color` and `colors` but see now
These two should just be on the same line.  Also add "." after ``'{key}'``.
Agreed, though I moved the key line to the previous line, makes it more readable.

This comes from a change in MPL being stricter about `set_xticks`. This worked for matplotlib 3.2

```python
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import string
import numpy as np

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(ncols=2, sharex=True)
ax1.boxplot([
    np.array([1, 2, 3, 4]),
    np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
])
ax2.boxplot([
    np.array([1, 2, 2, 3]),
    np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
])

ax1.set_xticklabels(['A', 'B'])
```

We set 2 x ticklabels despite there being 4.

Yes, this was a deliberate change... https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/17266  The obvious problem if you only give us 2 tick labels is that its ambiguous which of the 4 ticks you wanted labeled.  

MPL now has categorical axes which I think were added because pandas has them.  Probably too big a project to homogenize, but....
I've opened #36034 so that when reviewing we can  just click on and get definition as doesn't work for string literals (in VS Code anyway)
OT we could use data classes here
